item.title: StrandStorm
item.description: StrandStorm is a real-time hair rendering and simulation system built as a semester final project in spring 2023. It implements Kajiya-Kay and Marschner shading models, deep opacity maps for hair-to-hair self-shadowing, and physics-based strand simulation using discrete elastic rods with collision detection between strands and surfaces.

item.title: OpenGL Playground
item.description:
OpenGL Playground

A collection of graphics and simulation projects from spring 2023 coursework at the University of Utah, spanning Interactive Computer Graphics, Physics-Based Animation, and Computational Geometry. Written in C/C++ with GLSL shaders.

Features include directional, spot, and point lights with shadow mapping; interactive rigid body physics; a compute shader surface nets implementation; and a soft body physics solver.

item.title: Demon Island
item.description:
Demon Island is a multiplayer open-world adventure game written from scratch in C++ using SFML for networking, graphics, and audio — around 12,000 lines of code. The world is procedurally generated, with support for interiors, a basic combat system, and multiplayer that works over the internet.

Still in active development, with NPCs and procedural dungeons planned. Follow the itch.io page for semi-frequent devlogs.

item.title: Ludum Dare 52
item.description:
Dreamcatcher is a platformer made for Ludum Dare 52 (theme: “Harvest”). Playing as a dream harvester, you navigate a city at night — jumping between buildings, encircling dreams with the mouse to capture them before they transform into nightmares, and slashing nightmares to survive.

Free to play in the browser on itch.io.

item.title: Moviz
item.description:
Moviz is an interactive data visualization exploring the relationship between movies, their financial performance, critical ratings (IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes), and Academy Award recognition. Built with Alper Sahistan for a Data Visualization course at the University of Utah — it won runner-up best project.

The visualization lets you explore correlations across dimensions like budget, revenue, profit, runtime, and Oscar nominations/wins through an interactive scatter plot with filtering and search.

item.title: Petri
item.description: Petri is a high-performance particle life simulation written in Rust — an artificial life system where biologically-inspired agents evolve over time. It can handle 500,000+ particles at 60fps with simple collision physics.

item.title: WaifuXL
item.description: WaifuXL is a 100% client-side web tool for upscaling anime and graphic art using neural network-based super-resolution — all processing happens in the browser with no server required. Built collaboratively with friends at TheFutureGadgetsLab.

item.title: Ludum Dare 48
item.description:
I Stole a Wizard’s Sack and All I Got Was This Lousy Infinite Pocket Universe is a mind-warping puzzle game made solo for Ludum Dare 48 (theme: “Deeper and Deeper”). Built in Godot, the game features recursive, non-euclidean levels that fold in on themselves in unexpected ways. It won 2nd place in the Innovation category out of the jam’s entries.

Free to play in the browser on itch.io.

item.title: Ludum Dare 47
item.description:
Groovy B and the Great Cownundrum is a Groundhog Day-style time-loop adventure made for Ludum Dare 47 (theme: “Stuck in a Loop”). Players guide Groovy B through a town to unravel corruption in the local government and dairy industry — complete with adventure, mystery, romance, and milk.

Free to play in the browser on itch.io.

item.title: CUDA Raytracer
item.description:
A parallel raytracer built with CUDA and OpenGL, adapted from NVIDIA’s “Ray Tracing in One Weekend in CUDA” tutorial. The raytracing kernel runs entirely on the GPU, with OpenGL handling final display output.

The implementation supports diffuse, metallic (reflective), and dielectric (refractive) material types, along with plane and sphere primitives. Built and tested on Ubuntu with CUDA 10 and OpenGL 4.

item.title: Petting Zoo
item.description:
Petting Zoo is a framework for training neural network agents to play a procedurally generated Mario-style platformer using genetic algorithms. Supervised learning doesn’t apply well to games — there’s no predetermined “correct” input — so agents evolve through natural selection: they play levels, receive fitness scores, and successful models breed to produce improved generations.

The game environment generates endless level variety (gaps, spike platforms, changing floor heights) to prevent overfitting, while agents use feed-forward neural networks that map player vision inputs directly to button outputs.
